title: Barellan Point, Queensland
text:
Barellan Point is a <a href="rural%20residential">rural residential</a> <a href="Suburbs%20and%20localities%20%28Australia%29">suburb</a> in the <a href="City%20of%20Ipswich">City of Ipswich</a>, <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a>, Australia. In the Barellan Point had a population of 1,159 people.
Geography.
The suburb is bounded by the <a href="Brisbane%20River">Brisbane River</a> to the east and the <a href="Bremer%20River%20%28Queensland%29">Bremer River</a> to the south. It includes two uninhabited islands in the Brisbane River:
History.
In February 1864 <a href="John%20Petrie">John Petrie</a> appointed Irish engineer <a href="Joseph%20Brady%20%28engineer%29">Joseph Brady</a> to provide advice and designs for the navigational improvements on the <a href="Brisbane%20River">Brisbane</a> and <a href="Bremer%20River%20%28Queensland%29">Bremer Rivers</a> between <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a> and <a href="Ipswich%2C%20Queensland">Ipswich</a>. This includes the construction of a training wall at the south-eastern corner of Barrelan Point where the Bremer River flows into the Brisbane River to flow the channel to avoid the built-up of sandbanks.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the Barellan Point Landing Ground was built on an elevated level site by <a href="RAAF%20Base%20Amberley">RAAF Base Amberley</a>. It was also known as the Bremer River Landing Ground and Riverview Landing Ground. Originally built for emergency landings, it was also used by <a href="No.%2023%20Squadron%20RAAF">RAAF No 23 Squadron</a> as a training airfield and for their Moth Minor A21-7 operations. It was and went from present day Dampier Street to Fifth Avenue. After the war ended, the land reverted to its former use as farm land. A memorial and information board at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Junction Road () commemorate the landing ground. The memorial was officially unveiled on Friday 26 June 2015 by the <a href="Queensland%20Governor">Queensland Governor</a> <a href="Paul%20de%20Jersey">Paul de Jersey</a>.
On 12 July 1988 the <a href="Moreton%20Shire%20Council">Moreton Shire Council</a> officially opened Joseph Brady Park to commemorate Joseph Brady's engineering achievements at the site of one of his projects. It was a project undertaken as part of the <a href="Australian%20Bicentenary">Australian Bicentenary</a>.
At the Barellan Point had a population of 1,178 people.
In the Barellan Point had a population of 1,159 people.
